title: Carey Mulligan on "Suffragette": An 'Eye-Opening Experience'
text:
Carey Mulligan on "Suffragette": An 'Eye-Opening Experience' Posted today at 2:30pm 
Focus Features (LOS ANGELES) -- It seems very timely for a movie about women fighting for equality, and that's the focus of Suffragette , in select theaters Friday. 
Suffragette is about women fighting for the vote in England in the early 20th century, something its Oscar-nominated star, Carey Mulligan, tells ABC Radio she didn't learn much about in school. 
"The suffragette movement in my history book was a paragraph...so reading the script was a really eye-opening experience," she recalls. 
Mulligan, 30, hopes audiences will take something away from the movie. 
"There are so many issues in the film that we still struggle with," she notes. "Access to education for women, sexual violence, and women's representation in Parliament, all of these things are still things that we're dealing with today." 
Mulligan declares, "This film should have been made a long time ago." 
Equal pay in Hollywood has been a hot topic lately, with Jennifer Lawrence putting the spotlight on the issue. Has Mulligan ever had to fight for equal pay during her career? 
"Probably, but without knowing," she answers. "Because I'm not, I haven't sort of done lots of big blockbuster films so there's not sort of an obvious discrepancy I don't think, but I'm sure it's happened and I just haven't known about it, because it is so rife in our industry." 
Suffragette is slowly rolling out across the country, starting Friday.
